docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN it comes to feeding her family, Liz Kaplan buys organic products because, like many consumers, she says she believes that food grown without chemicals is healthier. She takes the same approach to her gardening and lawn care, and in the six years she has lived in her house in Sleepy Hollow, she has never used pesticides on her property. “It feels wrong to have any extra chemicals around,” Ms. Kaplan, 45, said.

headline.main: Homeowners Seek Safer Alternatives to Pesticides

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Ruffled Feathers'' (editorial, March 25):

headline.main: The Cost of Living In Connecticut

docs.abstract: Lars Bader letter on March 25 editorial holds high cost of living and working in Connecticut, rather than poor education or lack of universal health care, is what is driving out both residents and jobs
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Re ''Ruffled Feathers'' (editorial, March 25):
docs.section_name: Education; New York and Region; Opinion

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Aged, Frail and Denied Care by Their Insurers'' (''Golden Opportunities'' series, front page, March 26): Long-term care insurance can be a valuable tool for a family's long-term financial planning. It is important that consumers receive recommendations of policies based on their financial objectives. People should receive thorough disclosures and suitable products offered by properly trained and monitored sales professionals.
docs.abstract: Letter from Brian K Atchinson, president of Insurance Marketplace Standards Association, responds to March 26 article in series Golden Opportunities on companies offering long-term-care insurance to older Americans; says people should receive thorough disclosures and suitable products offered by properly trained and monitored sales professionals
